    Design and Structure–Activity Relationships of Isothiocyanates as Potent and Selective N-Acylethanolamine-Hydrolyzing Acid Amidase Inhibitors

    • Michael S. Malamas*
      Michael S. Malamas
      Northeastern University, Boston, Massachusetts 02115, United States
      *Email: [email protected]
      More by Michael S. Malamas
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-4785-7525

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    N-Acylethanolamines are signaling lipid molecules implicated in pathophysiological conditions associated with inflammation and pain. N-Acylethanolamine acid amidase (NAAA) favorably hydrolyzes lipid palmitoylethanolamide, which plays a key role in the regulation of inflammatory and pain processes. The synthesis and structure-activity relationship studies encompassing the isothiocyanate pharmacophore have produced potent low nanomolar inhibitors for hNAAA, while exhibiting high selectivity (>100-fold) against other serine hydrolases and cysteine peptidases. We have followed a target-based structure–activity relationship approach, supported by computational methods and known cocrystals of hNAAA. We have identified systemically active inhibitors with good plasma stability (t1/2 > 2 h) and microsomal stability (t1/2 ∼ 15–30 min) as pharmacological tools to investigate the role of NAAA in inflammation, pain, and drug addiction.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    N-Acylethanolamines (NAEs) are endogenous bioactive lipids that are implicated in many pathophysiological conditions, mostly associated with inflammation(1,2) and pain.(3−5) Also, recent reports suggest that the modulation of endogenous NAEs plays an important role in neurodegenerative diseases(6) and drug addiction.(7−9) The primary NAEs, arachidonoylethanolamine (AEA) and palmitoylethanolamide (PEA), exert their pharmacological action through two distinct molecular pathways. AEA suppresses inflammatory processes and promotes neuroprotective benefits by stimulating cannabinoid receptors CB1 and CB2,(6,10,11) while PEA displays anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective effects by activating nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPARα).(12−15) Both NAEs differ in their subcellular localization and substrate preference(16) and either independently or synergistically contribute to the pathophysiological conditions. AEA and PEA are synthesized “on-demand” in most mammalian cells(12,17) and their pharmacological action is modulated by two distinct hydrolases, fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH)(18) and N-acylethanolamine acid amidase (NAAA),(19,20) respectively. There is an abundance of data supporting the role of NAAA inhibition in various diseases, such as inflammation,(21−26) allergic dermatitis,(27) neuropathic pain,(28,29) multiple sclerosis,(30) and nicotine addiction.(7) To date, only a few systemic NAAA inhibitors are known(31,32) and there is a need to discover new inhibitors to fully explore the pharmacological benefits of inhibition of NAAA.

    Known NAAA Inhibitors

    The majority of the reported NAAA inhibitors represent β-lactone and β-lactam derivatives(21,31−34) (1 to 5; Figure 1) that showed nanomolar potency for the target. However, the majority exhibited poor plasma stability (t1/2 < 5 min) and moderate metabolic stability to be considered as development candidates.(35,36) One can consider that the reactive “war-heads” and lipophilic tails of the inhibitors are prone to hydrolytic and cytochrome P450 metabolic processes. It was also shown that β-lactone and β-lactam inhibitors form covalent adducts with the N-terminal catalytic cysteine Cys126 of hNAAA through an S-acylation process as determined by high-resolution MS/MS analysis of the modified peptide.(37−39) NAAA inhibitors 6 and 7 (Figure 1) carry reactive electrophilic groups, oxazolidinone and cyanamide, that most likely interact covalently with the catalytic Cys126 of NAAA. NAAA inhibitor 8 (Figure 1) represents the first reported reversible inhibitor for NAAA; however, it exhibited >20-fold drop in potency when compared to other irreversible inhibitors (Figure 1).
    In this paper, we describe a new class of NAAA inhibitors carrying the isothiocyanate (NCS) pharmacophore. NCS compounds occur widely in nature in cruciferous vegetables and are of interest in food science and medicine. Over the past 20 years, many studies have revealed that NCS compounds (natural or synthetic) are chemopreventive agents without any reports of adverse effects in clinical trials.(40−45) Still, there are no known NCS drugs in the market. Furthermore, it has been reported that NCS compounds readily react with alkyl thiols (R-SH) to form conjugate adducts (dithiocarbamates) in aqueous solutions. However, the dithiocarbamate adduct deconjugates over time to regenerate the NCS parent molecule and the corresponding thiol until a state of equilibrium is reached.(46) The rate of the adduct cleavage depends on the structural features of the thiol group and the overall shape of the ligand.(47) Both of these characteristics offer an opportunity to design molecules with a long residence time of the formed adduct and deliver a long-lasting pharmacodynamic effect. Notably, fully irreversible adducts have raised serious potential safety concerns in drug development because of the relationship between covalent drug binding and the potential of immunogenic driven allergic reactions and idiosyncratic drug toxicity.(48,49)

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Isothiocyanate NAAA Inhibitors

    We have recently published a novel series of cyanamide (N-CN) NAAA inhibitors with nanomolar potency for NAAA.(50) In this paper, we have exploited structural features of the N-CN inhibitors to design new NCS inhibitors (Figure 2). We have retained the biphenyl tail of cyanamide 9 and replaced the azetidine-nitrile moiety with a cyclobutane ring bearing the NCS pharmacophore (10, dotted lines, Figure 2). We have assumed that both ligands 9 and 10 are active site inhibitors. Conformational analysis of 9 and 10 (cis-isomer) produced a good overlap (cartoon A, Figure 2). The corresponding trans-isomer 11 (Table 1) overlapped poorly with 9 (not shown). The preparation and biochemical evaluation of the cis-isomer 10 for hNAAA using a fluorometric assay after a 90 min pre-incubation period revealed that 10 was a potent NAAA inhibitor (IC50 = 93 nM) but was 30-fold weaker than 9. The decrease in potency of 10 when compared to that of 9 was probably due to two factors: (1) the different electrophilic reactivities of the two pharmacophores NCS versus N-CN toward the nucleophilic sulfhydryl group of the catalytic cysteine Cys126 of hNAAA, with the N-CN group being more reactive and forming a tighter interaction (conjugate adduct) with Cys126 and (2) the different conformational adaptations of the NCS ligand 10 within the NAAA binding pocket when compared to that of 9. The NCS group is longer than the N-CN group and also the NCS group projects at an angular orientation because it is attached at the sp3 carbon of the cyclobutane ring. We have also prepared the analogous trans-isomer 11, and it was found to exhibit poor activity for NAAA with an IC50 value of 4.3 μM. To better assess the inhibitory potency of 10, we have determined the kinact/KI value, which is more representative to irreversible inhibition.(51) Compound 10 exhibited a high kinact/KI value of 7.23 × 106 M–1 s–1 (Table 1) suggesting the high affinity for NAAA.
    Table 1. Alkoxy-Linked Isothiocyanate hNAAA Inhibitors
    a

    IC50s performed in triplicate and determined from eight concentrations in the hNAAA inhibition assay. Activity measured after 90 min of pre-incubation of the inhibitor and enzyme prior to the addition of the fluorogenic substrate N-(4-methyl coumarin) palmitamide (PAMCA). IC50 values were calculated using Prism software (GraphPad).

    b

    Clog P values were calculated using ChemDraw version 16.0.

    Computer-Assisted Drug Design

    We have used computational methods to gain structural insights of the interactions of our ligands with NAAA. The disclosure of two cocrystal structures of hNAAA(52) offered us the opportunity to rationally design NCS-based ligands. We have constructed “pre-covalent” binding poses of the proposed molecules to examine their conformational adaptation within the NAAA binding pocket. For example, induced-fit pre-covalent studies (Figure 3) of 36 with a hNAAA structure (6DXX(66)) revealed the hydrophobic nature of the binding pocket of NAAA. Several hydrophobic residues Tyr146, Tyr177, Trp181, Phe174, and Met64 (Figure 4; ligand interaction diagram of 36/hNAAA) point to a highly hydrophobic pocket where the ligand is positioned by making several π-stacking interactions. Next, we performed covalent docking studies of 36 with NAAA, as shown in Figure 5. The NCS group of 36 interacts with the active site catalytic cysteine Cys126 to form a carbonimidodithioate adduct, while the rest of the ligand orients similarly to the pre-covalent binding pose (Figure 3). To expand the structure–activity relationships (SARs) of the NCS inhibitors, we have constructed “pre-covalent” NAAA-ligand poses using Glide/Prime(53,54) (Schrodinger) to determine inhibitor fit into the binding pocket with the correct binding geometry, We have calculated the lowest free-binding energy of the ligand by using the CovDock/Prime(55) method. Additionally, we have compared the conformations and binding energies of the docked ligands in induced-fit and covalent-docked poses to examine the alignment and adaptation of the ligand within the binding pocket before and after its interaction with catalytic cysteine Cys126 of NAAA. We also measured the proximity of the NCS group to Cys126 of the induced-fit ligand orientation to predict the carbonimidodithioate adduct formation. As part of our studies, we have also employed chemoinformatics calculations (i.e., MW, Clog P, tPSA, and LiPE) and applied the Lipinski’s Rule of Five to evaluate drug likeness.

    Synthesis

    The reported compounds were prepared according to general synthetic Schemes 1–4.

    Synthesis of Alkoxy Analogues (Scheme 1)

    Coupling of hydroxy cyclobutane 12 with 1-bromo-4-(bromomethyl)benzene upon treatment with sodium hydride in tetrahydrofuran afforded 13 (R1 = H). The palladium-mediated cross-coupling reaction between aryl bromide 13 (R1 = H) and an appropriate aryl boronic acid in the presence of tetrakis (triphenylphosphine) palladium (0), K2CO3, dioxane, and water produced biaryl 14 (R1 = H, R2 = aryl, heteroaryl). Unmasking the BOC group of 14 (R1 = H, R2 = aryl, heteroaryl) with trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) in dichloromethane afforded amine 15 (R1 = H, R2 = aryl, heteroaryl), which upon treatment with 1,1′-thiocarbonyldi-2(1H)-pyridone and triethylamine in dichloromethane afforded isothiocyanate 16 (R1 = H, R2 = aryl, heteroaryl).

    Synthesis of Phenoxy Analogues (Scheme 2)

    Hydroxy cyclobutane 12 was coupled with 4-bromo-phenol using the Mitsunobu protocol(56) (DIAD/Ph3P) to afford 17. Phenoxy 17 was converted to isothiocyanate 19 (R2= aryl) according to Scheme 1.

    Synthesis of Amino Analogues (Scheme 3)

    The reductive amination of 3-butanone 20 with amine 21 using sodium triacetoxy borohydride under acidic conditions (i.e., AcOH) produced 22. Intermediate 22 was converted to isothiocyanates 24a and 24b, according to Scheme 1. The cis- and trans-isomers 24a and 24b (n = 2) were separated by flash chromatography.

    Synthesis of Carboxamide/Sulfonamide Analogues (Scheme 4)

    Cyclobutyl-amine 25 was coupled with an appropriate benzoic acid in the presence N-ethyl-N′-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide (EDC)/HOBt to afford amide 26. Also, the coupling of 25 with an appropriate benzenesulfonyl chloride in the presence of DIEA afforded sulfonamide 27. Both, amide 26 and sulfonamide 27 were converted to isothiocyanates 28 and 29, respectively, according to Scheme 1.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    All synthesized compounds were assessed in a fluorescence-based assay for hNAAA inhibition with N-(4-methyl coumarin)palmitamide (PAMCA) as the substrate.(57) The SAR development of this series of inhibitors was based on IC50 determinations at 90 min pre-incubation experiments, where we have attained full ligand/enzyme engagement (Tables 1−4). We have also performed kinact/KI determinations that are independent of pre-incubation times and represent a better measure of potency of covalent inhibitors (Table 1). Compounds that inhibited hNAAA with an IC50 value of <30 nM were further evaluated in selectivity counterscreen assays. First, they were tested for their ability to inhibit human-recombinant FAAH (hFAAH)(58) using the fluorogenic substrate arachidonoyl 7-amino-4-methylcoumarin amide (AAMCA).(59,60) Following similar fluorometric procedures, compounds that were found to be >100-fold selective against FAAH were tested against the hydrolytic enzymes human monoacylglycerol lipase (hMGL)(61) and human α/β-hydrolase domain containing 6 (hABHD6).(62) Also, the selected potent NAAA inhibitors were evaluated against the related cysteine peptidase cathepsin K for selectivity because NAAA is a cysteine peptidase that belongs to the N-terminal nucleophile (Ntn) family of enzymes.(20) Furthermore, the selected compounds were evaluated for their ability to bind to CB1 and CB2 receptors using rat brain(63) or HEK293 cell membranes expressing mouse CB2 (mCB2) or human CB2 (hCB2),(64−66) respectively, via competition equilibrium binding using [3H]CP-55,940(65−67) to minimize/eliminate any potential cross-reactivity due to potential common pharmacophoric features. Below, we describe our SAR studies of a selection of compounds, as shown in Tables 1–4.
    Table 2. N-Linked Isothiocyanate hNAAA Inhibitors
    a

    IC50s performed in triplicate and determined from eight concentrations in the hNAAA inhibition assay. Activity measured after 90 min of pre-incubation of the inhibitor and enzyme prior to the addition of the fluorogenic substrate PAMCA. IC50 values were calculated using Prism software (GraphPad).

    b

    Clog P values were calculated using ChemDraw version 16.0.

    Table 3. Carboxamide-/Sulfonamide-Linked Isothiocyanate hNAAA Inhibitors
    compdR1XWhNAAA IC50 (nM) ± SEMaacathepsin K @ 1 μMbClog Pc
    614-OMe,3-FPhNCONH26.6 ± 0.6inactive3.67
    624-OMePhNCONH7.6 ± 0.9inactive3.65
    63MeSO2PhNCONH41% @ 1 μM 2.11
    644-OMePhNSO2NH6.3 ± 0.4inactive3.78
    654-OMePhCSO2NH2.3 ± 0.35inactive4.06
    664-OMe,3-FPhCSO2NH3.2 ± 0.15inactive4.12
    674-OMePhCOCONH7.0 ± 0.3 4.21
    684-OMePhOCCONH1416 ± 14 4.16
    a

    IC50s performed in triplicate and determined from eight concentrations in the hNAAA inhibition assay. Activity measured after 90 min of pre-incubation of the inhibitor and enzyme prior to the addition of the fluorogenic substrate PAMCA. IC50 values were calculated using Prism software (GraphPad).

    b

    Compounds were tested in triplicate and pre-incubated for 120 min with recombinant human cathepsin K. We used the fluorogenic substrate Z-Phe-Arg-AMC.

    c

    Clog P values were calculated using ChemDraw version 16.0.

    Table 4. Polar and Aliphatic Isothiocyanate hNAAA Inhibitors
    a

    IC50s performed in triplicate and determined from eight concentrations in the hNAAA inhibition assay. Activity measured after 90 min of pre-incubation of the inhibitor and enzyme prior to the addition of the fluorogenic substrate PAMCA. IC50 values were calculated using Prism software (GraphPad).

    b

    Clog P values were calculated using ChemDraw version 16.0.

    Substitutions of Lead Compound 10 (Table 1)

    We have introduced substitutions at the distal phenyl group of lead compound 10 (Table 1) to maximize van der Waals hydrophobic contacts between the ligand and protein to enhance potency for the target, considering the hydrophobic nature of the binding pocket of NAAA. The para-methyl analogue 30a was about 3-fold more potent than the unsubstituted analogue 10. Both trans-isomers 11 and 30b were about 20–40-fold weaker than the analogous cis-isomers 10 and 30a, respectively. The meta-methoxy analogue 31 was 4-fold more potent than 10, while the meta-trifluoromethyl analogue 32 was only slightly better than 10. Analogue 32 also carries a second modification with the introduction of the metabolically stable fluorine group at the proximal phenyl moiety of the ligand to limit cytochrome P450 oxidation. The introduction of an electronegative fluorine group at the para-position of the distal phenyl (entry 33) caused a 7-fold drop in potency (33 vs 31). Interchanging the two phenyl substituents of 33 to generate the 4-OMe, 3-FPh-analogue 34 resulted in the recovery of potency (34 vs 33). In contrast, the para-OCF3 group (35) caused a 4-fold potency loss. We have postulated that the presence of electronegative groups (F, OCF3) at the para-position of the distal phenyl of 33 and 35 have triggered unfavorable electrostatic contacts with the residues of the binding pocket causing loss in potency. The more polar analogue, pyridine 36, showed similar potency (IC50 = 20 nM) for NAAA when it was compared to 34. We were aiming at increasing the hydrophilic character of 36 with the introduction the polar pyridyl nucleus to improve water solubility and bioavailability. Compound 36 has a 1.5 units lower Clog P value than 34 (3.38 vs 4.89, respectively). Induced-fit molecular modeling studies of 36 with the hNAAA X-ray crystal structure (Figure 3) suggested that hydrophobic substituents at the distal phenyl group of the ligand contributed to increased ligand affinity by making favorable van der Waals hydrophobic interactions with backbone hydrophobic residues (i.e., Met64). Next, we investigated bulkier substituents at the para-position of the distal phenyl (entries 37 and 38). We have observed that when bulkiness increased in the order Me < Et < i-Pr, the ligand potency decreased. The ethyl analogue 37 was 3-fold weaker than methyl analogue 34, while the bulkier isopropyl 38 was 10-fold weaker. Furthermore, both the longer benzyloxy analogue 39, and the bulkier 3,4-disubstituted methoxy analogue 40 showed reductions in potency. Molecular modeling studies have pointed to the limited available space at the vicinity of the para-phenyl substituent (not shown), which caused steric conflicts between the ligand and protein resulting in the loss of potency. Next, we probed further this region of the molecule by employing fused moieties, as shown in entries 41–45. Dioxine 41, dioxole 42, dihydrobenzofuran 43, and benzofuran 45 exhibited about 4–10-fold increases in potency when compared to dimethoxy analogue 40. Dihydrobenzofuran analogue 43 was the most potent analogue with an IC50 value of 4.5 nM. Surprisingly, the analogous regioisomeric dihydrobenzofuran 45 showed a marked loss (>10-fold) in potency (44 vs 43). 2,2-difluoro-dioxole 46 showed a marked 20-fold drop in potency (46 vs 42), further endorsing our earlier findings with 33 and 35, where the electronegative groups at the para-position of the distal phenyl were poorly tolerated causing loss in potency. Next, we investigated if polar groups at the distal aromatic region of the molecule were tolerated to improve water solubility. 5-OMe-pyridyl 48 showed good potency for NAAA (IC50 =30.4 nM), while 2-OMe-pyridyl 47 and pyrazole 49 analogues (Table 1) were found to be about 10-fold less potent than 34. In addition, the replacement of the proximal phenyl group of 34 with a pyridine nucleus (entries 36, 50, 51; Table 1) did not affect ligand potency. Also, in an attempt to further improve the water solubility of pyridine 36 (Clog P 3.38), we have prepared the corresponding polar N-oxide analogue 52 (Clog P 1.52), which showed almost two units of reduction in the Clog P value without any loss of potency (52 vs 36). Next, we shortened the linker between the proximal phenyl and cyclobutane ring to eliminate the benzylic position of the molecule, which is prone to CYP450 oxidation. The phenoxy analogue 53 was about 2-fold weaker than the parent compound 34. We have also introduced a methyl group at the benzylic position of the methoxy-linker region of 34 (entry 54; Table 1) to block any potential cytochrome P450 oxidative metabolism at this site. Methyl analogue 54 showed similar potency to that of the parent compound 34. Finally, we examined substitutions at the cyclobutane ring of the ligand, close to the NCS pharmacophore, to examine the impact on ligand affinity. The gem-dimethyl cyclobutane analogue 55 (Table 1) was 10-fold weaker than the unsubstituted analogue 36, while the bridged bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane analogue 56 was even weaker, which is indicative that bulkiness at the vicinity of the NCS pharmacophore was poorly tolerated.

    Amine-Linked Isothiocyanate Analogues (Table 2)

    We have prepared amine-linked analogues that are more hydrophilic and can facilitate salt formation to increase the water solubility of the molecule.
    N-Methylamine 57 showed a marked drop (20-fold) in potency (57 vs 10). The bicyclic amines isoquinoline 58 and tetrahydroisoquinoline 59 were 4-fold weaker than biphenyl 34, while the regioisomeric tetrahydroisoquinoline 60 was even weaker. Molecular modeling studies pointed to a more preferable alignment of the linear isomer 59 within the NAAA binding pocket when compared of that of 60 (not shown).

    Carboxamide- and Sulfonamide-Linked Analogues (Table 3)

    Next, we have replaced the methoxy linker of 34 and 36 with amide and sulfonamide functional groups to: (1) eliminate cytochrome P450 oxidative metabolism at the benzylic position and (2) explore hydrogen-bonding interactions between the amide and sulfonamide moieties and NAAA to enhance ligand affinity. Molecular modeling studies have revealed the presence of Ser123 (Figure 3) at the vicinity of the linker region that could potentially participate in hydrogen-bonding interaction(s) with amide and sulfonamide functionalities and enhance ligand affinity. Amide 61 showed similar potency to that of 36 for NAAA, while eliminating the fluorine group of the distal phenyl (entry 62), which resulted in a 3-fold increase of potency (62 vs 61). The introduction of the hydrophilic MeSO2 group as a potential bioisostere of the methoxy group (entry 63) was found to be detrimental to ligand’s potency (IC50 > 1 μM). Next, we have prepared sulfonamide-linked analogues 64–66, which exhibited comparable nanomolar potency when compared to the amide analogues (62 vs 64). Furthermore, the carbamate analogue 67 was found to be highly potent for NAAA with an IC50 value of 7 nM, while the phenoxy analogue 68 was weakly active IC50 = 1.4 μM (68 vs 62), which is indicative that the shorter biaryl tail was important for good ligand affinity to NAAA.

    Modifications of the Proximal Phenyl Group of the Biphenyl Nucleus (Table 4)

    While only limited polar modifications at the distal phenyl moiety of the biphenyl nucleus were tolerated on retaining good affinity for NAAA, we were also interested in exploring polar modifications at the proximal phenyl to improve water solubility and oral bioavailability. The introduction of the isoxazole moiety (69) resulted in a 12-fold decrease of potency (69 vs 62), while the oxazole analogue 70 was weakly active (IC50 ∼ 1 μM). Surprisingly, pyrazine 71 was also found to be 100-fold weaker than the analogous pyridine analogue 62. This was a bit unexpected finding and molecular modeling studies could not explain this dramatic drop in potency of 71. One can postulate that unfavorable electrostatic conflicts between the ligand and protein due to the presence of the two nitrogen atoms at the pyrazine nucleus might have contributed to such marked loss in potency. The methoxy-linked isoxazole 72 showed good activity for NAAA with an IC50 value of 43.6 nM, while oxadiazole 73 was 10-fold weaker than 72. The loss in potency of 73 is reminiscent to the loss in potency with pyrazine 71, further demonstrating the intolerability of two nitrogen atoms present at the same nucleus (i.e., pyrazine and oxadiazole).
    The introduction of a piperidine nucleus (entry 74) resulted in about 20-fold of potency (74 vs 62), while the cyclobutane analogue 75 was about 2-fold better than the bulkier bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane analogue 76. The alkyl-tailed analogues 77 and 78 were also weaker than biaryl 62, but the longer C5-linker analogue 78 was 3-fold more potent (IC50 = 22.5 nM) than the shorter analogue 77. These findings are supported by the earlier reported NAAA inhibitors carrying alkyl hydrophobic tails.(36)

    Modifications of the Cyclobutane Ring of the Ligand (Table 5)

    Finally, we have altered the size and polarity of the cyclobutane ring of the molecule. As shown in Table 5, the cyclopentane analogue 79 was found to be weakly active for NAAA, dropping 70-fold in potency when compared to the analogous cyclobutane analogue 36. One can postulate that 79 is aligning within the NAAA binding-pocket quite distinctly than 36 and positioning the NCS group remotely from the catalytic Cys126 to form a carbonimidodithioate adduct. The more linear ligand 1,4-disubstituted cyclohexyl analogue 80 was about 3-fold more potent than 79, while the angular 1,3-disubstituted cyclohexyl ligand 81 was practically inactive for NAAA. Next, we replaced the cyclobutane ring with a polar azetidine moiety 82. This modification has caused an 8-fold loss in potency (82 vs 35); however, the incorporation of the more flexible C6-phenyl tail (entry 83) markedly enhanced ligand potency (IC50 = 8.3 nM). This observation coincided with the findings of the first-generation NAAA inhibitors(35,36) (Figure 1), where inhibitors carrying flexible phenyl-alkyl tails exhibited high potency for NAAA. Finally, analogue 84 was prepared to support our metabolic studies with the addition of a methyl group at the cyclobutane ring, which caused >20-fold loss in potency (84 vs 35).
    Table 5. Various Ring-Size Isothiocyanate hNAAA Inhibitors
    a

    IC50s performed in triplicate and determined from eight concentrations in the hNAAA inhibition assay. Activity measured after 90 min of pre-incubation of the inhibitor and enzyme prior to the addition of the fluorogenic substrate PAMCA. IC50 values were calculated using Prism software (GraphPad).

    b

    Clog P values were calculated using ChemDraw version 16.0.

    Selectivity Profile of Isothiocyanate NAAA Inhibitors

    All the prepared NAAA inhibitors with IC50 values of <30 nM were evaluated against serine hydrolases hFAAH, hMGL, and hABHD6 at a 1 μM concentration and were found to be inactive. Also, they lacked affinity against the cannabinoid CB1 and CB2 receptors at 1 μM concentration. Notwithstanding NAAA’s functional similarity with FAAH, both known to degrade NAEs,(20,68) NAAA shares no homology with FAAH or other enzymes of the same “amidase signature” family.(20) NAAA is a cysteine protease that belongs to the Ntn family of lysosomal enzymes(20) and closely relates to 11-membered family of cathepsins.(69) We have evaluated several NAAA inhibitors against cathepsin K (Tables 3 and 6). All the tested NAAA inhibitors with a methoxy linker between the proximal phenyl group and the cyclobutane ring of the ligand inhibited cathepsin K with IC50 values of about 50–100 nM (Table 6). In contrast, when we replaced the methoxy linker with either carboxamide or sulfonamide linkers, the new ligands were found to be inactive against cathepsin K at 1 μM concentration (Table 3). We have postulated that either the constrained nature of the carboxamide and sulfonamide linkers or their electrophilic nature could have altered the recognition of the ligand against cathepsin K, resulting in lower binding affinity.
    Table 6. Evaluation of Isothiocyanate hNAAA Inhibitors against Cathepsin K
    compdcathepsin K IC50 (nM)a
    3456.50 @ 100 nM
    3558.6
    36120.5
    4383.5
    45[email protected] 100 nM
    5043.7 @100 nM
    5156.75 @ 100 nM
    a

    IC50s performed in triplicate. Compounds were pre-incubated for 120 min with recombinant human cathepsin K. We used the fluorogenic substrate Z-Phe-Arg-AMC. IC50 values were calculated using Prism software (GraphPad).

    Stability of Isothiocyanate NAAA Inhibitors (Table 7)

    Several inhibitors were evaluated in plasma stability assays (human, rat, and mouse) and demonstrated good plasma stability t1/2 > 2 h (not shown). Furthermore, we have evaluated several NCS NAAA inhibitors in human, rat, and mouse liver microsomal preparations for metabolic stability (Table 7). Biaryl analogues 10, 32, and 36 showed good metabolic stability, t1/2 ∼15–28 min, while the remaining were only weakly stable t1/2 ∼ 3–10 min. The introduction of various substitutions consisting of metabolic stable groups (i.e., F and CF3) to minimize cytochrome P450 oxidative metabolism and modifications of the methoxy linker of the parent compound with carboxamide and sulfonamide moieties produced only modest benefits.
    Table 7. Microsomal Stability of Isothiocyanate hNAAA Inhibitors
    t1/2 min
    compdhumanratmouse
    1016.119.614.4
    321617.913.2
    3510.99.12.9
    3616.719.228.2
    423.36.52.4
    4715.314.56.8
    507.17.46.3
    5111.810.25.1
    5714.74.45.1
    61138.614
    66866
    676.456.2

    Metabolite Identification Studies

    Next, we conducted metabolite identification studies to gain insights of the potential metabolic liabilities of the cyclobutane and NCS groups of the molecule. We have investigated analogue 47 (Table 7) and identified two metabolic “soft spots” (Figure 6). MS/MS fragmentation pattern analysis was consistent with two major metabolites A and B, resulting from the fragmentation of the NCS group to corresponding amine A (fragment 303) and cleavage of the bond attached at the cyclobutane ring to afford benzylic alcohol B (fragment 234). Both metabolites were confirmed by comparison to authentic synthetic compounds. The formation of B occurred by the oxidation of the cyclobutane ring at position-1 (Figure 6) that produced an unstable hemiketal intermediate, which further degraded to metabolite B. We have attempted to block this position with the addition of a methyl group at position-1 of the cyclobutane ring (Figure 6). Unfortunately, the synthesized methyl analogue (84) was only weakly active (IC50 = 480 nM) for NAAA. Also, as we discussed above, various modifications of the benzylic linker have not translated to more stable molecules (Table 7).
    Furthermore, we have studied the fragmentation of the NCS group to produce metabolite A. The NCS group conjugates with sulfhydryl groups to form dithiocarbamate adducts. We have conducted metabolic studies with 47 using cysteine as the trapping nucleophile with and without NADPH activation. Figure 7 outlines the potential pathway for the formation of metabolite A. Without NADPH activation, we have observed only dithiocarbamate adduct C, while with NADPH activation, we have observed thiocarbamate adduct D. The formation of this adduct could be derived from the isocyanate intermediate E (P450-driven oxidative desulfurization). Moreover, isocyanate E is highly unstable in aqueous media and can easily degrade to metabolite A. Likely, these two metabolic fragmentations are the primary contributors to the metabolic instability of this series of NAAA inhibitors.

    Cassette Dosing Pharmacokinetics of NAAA Inhibitors (Table 8)

    We have assessed the pharmacokinetic properties of several NAAA inhibitors. First, we conducted pharmacokinetic cassette experiments to assess the drug concentrations in the plasma and brain in male CD-1 mice (Charles River), applying an intravenous dose of 2 mg/kg and an oral dose of 8 mg/kg at 15, 30, and 60 min timepoints (n = 3 animals per time point). The findings shown in Table 8 suggested that the majority of the NCS NAAA inhibitors exhibited low plasma levels but higher drug levels in the brain.
    Table 8. Cassette Dosing Pharmacokinetics of the Selected Isothiocyanate NAAA Inhibitorsa
    compd15 min IV brain (μg/g)15 min IV plasma (μg/mL)30 min oral plasma (μg/mL)60 min oral plasma (μg/mL)
    320.81 ± 0.171.01 ± 0.270.019 ± 0.070.331 ± 0.21
    350.008 ± 0.0050.178 ± 0.0440.012 ± 0.0020.007 ± 0.003
    360.873 ± 0.2840.189 ± 0.050.016 ± 0.0020.054 ± 0.062
    410.012 ± 0.0020.168 ± 0.050.012 ± 0.0020.007 ± 0.003
    420.014 ± 0.0090.244 ± 0.0820.031 ± 0.0040.013 ± 0.006
    610.69 ± 0.1810.264 ± 0.0570.011 ± 0.0050.008 ± 0.001
    620.809 ± 0.2250.264 ± 0.0570.012 ± 0.0050.008 ± 0.001
    641.15 ± 0.320.126 ± 0.0130.003 ± 0.0020.002 ± 0.0003
    651.09 ± 0.620.164 ± 0.0570.02 ± 0.0020.02 ± 0.001
    a

    Male CD-1 mice (Charles River) following a single intravenous dose of NAAA inhibitor 2 mg/kg and an oral dose of 8 mg/kg at 15, 30 and 60 min time points (n = 3 animals per time point).

    Pharmacokinetic Study of 36

    Male CD-1 mice (25–30 g) from Charles River were used to determine the oral bioavailability and brain exposure of 36 after intravenous (iv) and oral (po) administration. Animals were fasted overnight prior to dosing and until 4 h post-dose. Mice were given 2 mg/kg of compound 36 intravenously and 8 mg/kg orally in 3% DMSO, 1:1:18 Emulphor/ethanol/saline vehicle.
    In Table 9, we summarize the findings of the studies. Compound 36 showed moderate bioavailability 13% and high brain penetrability (AUCbrain/AUCplasma 3.8; iv dosing).
    Table 9. Pharmacokinetic Study of Compound 36a
    dose2 mg/kg IV8 mg/kg PO
    Plasma
    AUC (min·μg/mL/kg)4.71 ± 0.562.48 ± 0.46
    clearance (mL/min/kg)4122763
    volume of distribution (L/kg)27126

    a

    Male CD-1 mice were given 36 at the dose of 2 mg/kg iv and 8 mg/kg po in vehicle 3% DMSO, 1:1:18 Emulphor/ethanol/saline; n = 3 animals per time point.

    Safety Profile of NAAA Inhibitor 36

    NCS compounds natural or synthetic have been reported as chemopreventive agents and lacked any adverse effects in clinical trials.(40−45) We have studied NAAA inhibitor 36 in CEREP “off-target” panels consisting of receptors (i.e., 5HT1A, 5HT2A, 5HT2C, DA D1, DA D2, DA D3, DA D4.4, delta-opioid, κ-opioid, and μ-opioid) and transporters (i.e., DAT, SERT, and NET). Additionally, we have evaluated 36 in various cytochrome P450 isoforms CYP1A2, CYP2A6, CYP3A4, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, and CYP2D6 for inhibition; in vitro safety pharmacology against hERG for potential QT prolongation; and Ames test strains of TA98, TA100, TA1535, and TA1537 with and without metabolic activation by rat liver microsome fraction S9 for mutagenicity. Compound 36 remarkably showed nominal “off-target” effects in 70 assays of receptors, ion channels, and enzymes at 10 μM concentrations (Table 10). Only CYP-isozymes, 1A2, 2C19, and 3A4, have raised some concerns, nevertheless at micromolar concentrations. Also, 36 was found to be negative in the Ames test and weakly active against hERG.
    Table 10. Compound 36 “Off-Target” Profile
    CYP inhibition: CYP2D6, CYP2A6, CYP2C9—no effect at 10 μM IC50 μM: CYP1A2 = 1.8, CYP2C19 = 3.3, CYP3A4 = 2.6
    CEREP: panel of receptors, ion channels, and enzymes 70 assays—no effect at 10 μM
    transporters: DAT, SERT, and NET—no effect at 10 μM
    AMES: TA98, TA100, TA1535, and TA1537 with and without metabolic activation by rat liver microsomes fraction S9 (5–100 μM range, in duplicate)—negative AMES
    hERG: IC50 = 19 μM
    We have selected NAAA inhibitor 36 as a promising pharmacological tool compound to study addictive disorders (nicotine addiction, and opioids), gastrointestinal inflammatory diseases (ulcerative colitis), and autoimmune encephalomyelitis, a type of inflammation of the brain and spinal cord. We have recently published the role of NAAA inhibitor 36 in nicotine addiction.(7) Our findings supported NAAA inhibitor 36 as a new pharmacological tool to modulate PEA/PPAR-α signaling in the brain by reducing nicotine’s rewarding properties as a promising smoking cessation therapy.(7)

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We have identified a new series of potent and selective isothiocyanate NAAA inhibitors with nanomolar potency. NAAA is the primary hydrolytic enzyme of lipid PEA, which is an agonist of the nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-α (PPAR-α). The PEA/PPAR-α signaling pathway has been implicated in many diseases, such inflammation,(70,71) pain,(2,72) and neuroprotection.(73) The new NAAA inhibitors showed low nanomolar inhibitory activity against human NAAA and were selective (>100-fold) against serine hydrolases and cysteine peptidase. Also, they lacked affinity for the cannabinoid receptors CB1 and CB2. We have followed a target-based SAR approach, supported by computational methods and known cocrystals of hNAAA. We have constructed “pre-covalent” NAAA-ligand complexes to identify good ligand binding geometries within the binding pocket of NAAA and then calculated covalent docking poses of the formed adducts (with catalytic cysteine Cys126) to select compounds for synthesis. Several inhibitors demonstrated good plasma stability (t1/2 > 2 h; human and rodents) and good microsomal stability (t1/2 ∼ 15–28 min; human and rodents). We have identified a robust systemically available tool compound 36 with excellent brain penetrability, and we have successfully completed studies as a potential candidate for nicotine addiction/smoking cessation.(7) Furthermore, several of the disclosed isothiocyanate NAAA inhibitors represent promising pharmacological tools to investigate the role of NAAA in inflammation and pain.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry

    All solvents and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and were used as received. All nonaqueous reactions were carried out in oven-dried glassware under an atmosphere of dried argon or nitrogen. All reactions were monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC plates F254, Merck) or LC–MS analysis. All products, unless otherwise noted, were purified by flash chromatography using Biotage purification system and pre-packed silica cartridges. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were obtained on a VARIAN 400 spectrometer at 500 MHz. Spectra are given in ppm (δ) and coupling constants, J values, are reported in hertz. Splitting patterns are designated as follows: s, singlet; brs, broad singlet; d, doublet; t, triplet; q, quartet; and m, multiplet. Tetramethylsilane was used as an internal reference standard. Mass spectra were obtained on a Waters Micromass ZQ spectrometer. 1H NMR, HPLC, and mass spectrometry were used to determine the purity of the compounds. The purity of all final products was >96% as determined by LC–MS using the following protocol. Mobile phase A = water, B = acetonitrile solvent gradient 95/5 to 5/95 A/B in 11 min; flow rate: 1.5 mL/min; Waters XTerra MS C8 column (4.6 × 50 mm) with UV detection at 190–400 nm wavelength.

    Method A (Scheme 1)

    4-(((1s,3s)-3-Isothiocyanatocyclobutoxy)methyl)-4′-methyl-1,1′-biphenyl (30a) and 4-(((1R,3R)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutoxy)methyl)-4′-methyl-1,1′-biphenyl (30b)

    Step a
    Sodium hydride (60% dispersion in mineral oil; 58.8 mg, 1.47 mmol) was added into a cold (0 °C) mixture of tert-butyl (3-hydroxycyclobutyl)carbamate (260 mg, 1.39 mmol) and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF) (5 mL). After stirring for 1 h, 1-bromo-4-(bromomethyl)benzene (422 mg, 1.69 mmol) was added and the mixture was allowed to come to room temperature and stirred for 8 h. Then, the mixture was poured into saturated aqueous ammonium chloride and extracted twice with ethyl acetate. The organic extracts were dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvents were removed under vacuum, and the residue was purified on silica gel (Biotage; eluting solvents: hexanes/EtOAc in a 4/1 ratio) to afford tert-butyl (3-((4-bromobenzyl)oxy)cyclobutyl)carbamate as oil (382 mg, 63.5% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.47 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.2 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 4.61 (m, 1H), 4.35 (s, 2H), [4.16(m), 3.76–3.7 (m), 2H], [2.71–2.7 (m), 2.41(m), 2H], [2.14 (m), 1.82–1.76 (m), 2H], 1.43 (s, 9H); MS (ES) m/z: 356.12 [M + 1]+.
    Step b
    Into a microwave vessel were added tert-butyl (3-((4-bromobenzyl)oxy)cyclobutyl)carbamate (150 mg, 0.42 mmol), p-tolyl-boronic acid (114.2 mg, 0.84 mmol), K2CO3 (174 mg, 1.26 mmol), dioxane (8 mL), and water (2 mL). The argon gas was passed through the mixture for 10 min, then tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(0) (4.8 mg 0.0042 mmol) was added, and the argon flow was continued for 5 additional minutes. Then, the vessel was sealed and microwaved at 110 °C for 2 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, diluted with EtOAc (30 mL), and washed with water and brine. The organic extracts were dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvents were removed under vacuum, and the residue was purified on silica gel (Biotage; eluting solvent hexanes: EtOAc 4/1 ratio) to afford tert-butyl (3-((4′-methyl-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)methoxy)cyclobutyl)carbamate as oil (123.8 mg, 80% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.56 (dd, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.49 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.38 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.25 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 4.61 (m, 1H), 4.43 (s, 2H), [4.27–4.21 (m), 3.79–3.57 (m) 2H], [2.72 (m), 2.42 (m), 2H], [2.18 (m), 1.85–1.79 (m), 2H], 1.43 (s, 9H); MS (ES) m/z: 368.22 [M + 1]+.
    Step c
    TFA (0.25 mL, 3.26 mmol) was added into a mixture of tert-butyl (3-((4′-methyl-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)methoxy)cyclobutyl)carbamate (120 mg, 0.32 mmol) and CH2Cl2 (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5 h, and then, the volatiles were removed under vacuum. The residue was successively taken three times in CHCl3 (10 mL) and the volatiles were removed under vacuum to ensure the removal of the excess TFA. The crude 3-((4′-methyl-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)methoxy)cyclobutan-1-amine. TFA salt A salt (122 mg) was carried to the next step without any further purification.
    Step d
    Trimethylamine (0.33 mL, 2.35 mmol) was added into a mixture of 3-((4′-methyl-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)methoxy)cyclobutan-1-amine. TFA salt (122 mg, 0.32 mmol) and CH2Cl2 (5 mL). After stirring for 10 min, 1,1′-thiocarbonyldi-2(1H)-pyridone (222.7 mg, 0.96 mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred at temperature for 2 h. The mixture was diluted in EtOAc (30 mL) and washed with water and brine. The organic extracts were dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvents were removed under vacuum, and the residue was purified on silica gel (Biotage; eluting solvents: hexanes/EtOAc in a 15/1 ratio) to afford 30b 4-(((1R,3R)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutoxy)methyl)-4′-methyl-1,1′-biphenyl as oil (12.6 mg), 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.57 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.49 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.37 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.25 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 4.44 (s, 2H), 4.37–4.34 (m, 1H), 4.31–4.27 (m, 1H), 2.51–2.48 (m, 4H), 2.39 (s, 3H); MS (ES) m/z: 310.1112 [M + 1]+; and 30a 4-(((1s,3s)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutoxy)methyl)-4′-methyl-1,1′-biphenyl (79.8 mg), 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.57 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.49 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.37 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.25 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 4.45 (s, 2H), 3.81–3.78 (m, 1H), 3.71–3.68 (m, 1H), 2.82–2.76 (m, 2H), 2.39 (s, 3H), 2.33–2.27 (m, 2H); MS (ES) m/z: 310.1081 [M + 1]+; purity: 100%, retention time: 5.5 min.

    Method B (Scheme 2)

    3-Fluoro-4’-((1s,3s)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutoxy)-4-methoxy-1,1′-biphenyl (53)

    Strep a
    Diisopropyl azodicarboxylate (0.76 mL, 3.88 mmol) was added into a mixture of tert-butyl ((1s,3s)-3-hydroxycyclobutyl)carbamate (485 mg, 2.59 mmol), 4-bromophenol (538 mg, 3.11 mmol), and anhydrous THF (25 mL). The mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 8 h and then poured into water and extracted with EtOAc. The organic extracts were washed with brine and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvents were removed under vacuum and the residue was purified on silica gel (Biotage; eluting solvents: hexanes/EtOAc in a 4/1 ratio) to afford tert-butyl ((1s,3s)-3-(4-bromophenoxy)cyclobutyl)carbamate as oil (487 mg, 55% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.33 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.31 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.74 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.64 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 4.79 (br s, 1H), 4.74–4.71 (m, 2H), 4.31–4.29 (m, 1H), 2.56–2.51 (m, 2H), 2.37–2.36 (m, 2), 1.45 (s, 9H); MS (ES) m/z: 342.08 [M + 1]+.
    Step b
    tert-Butyl ((1s,3s)-3-(4-bromophenoxy)cyclobutyl)carbamate was converted to 53 according to method A (Scheme 1). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.54 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.28–7.23 (m, 2H), 7.0 (t, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 6.84 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 4.45–4.40 (m, 1H), 3.94–3.86 (m, 1H), 3.05–3.03 (m, 2H), 2.53–2.47 (m, 2H); MS (ES) m/z: 330.1102 [M + 1]+; purity: 98%, retention time: 5.35 min.

    Method C (Scheme 3)

    (1s,3s)-N-([1,1′-Biphenyl]-4-ylmethyl)-3-isothiocyanato-N-methylcyclobutan-1-amine (57)

    Step a
    To a mixture of 1-([1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)-N-methylmethanamine hydrochloride (254 mg, 1.09 mmol), tert-butyl (3-oxocyclobutyl)carbamate (183 mg, 0.99 mmol), acetic acid (0.17 mL), and anhydrous THF (3 mL) was added sodiumtriacetoxy borohydride (292 mg, 1.39 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 5 h and then was quenched with saturated aqueous sodium bicarbonate. The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate, washed with brine, and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvents were removed under vacuum, and the residue was purified on silica gel (Biotage; eluting solvents: hexanes/EtOAc in a 2/1 ratio) to afford tert-butyl (3-(([1,1′-biphenyl]-4-ylmethyl) (methyl)amino)cyclobutyl)carbamate as oil (351 mg, 96.9% yield): 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.6 (d, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H), 7.5 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.4 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.35 (m, 3H), [4.82 (m), 4.62 (m), 1H], [4.13 (m), 3.86 (m), 1H], 3.4 (s, 2H), [3.08–3.05 (m), 2.57–2.54 (m), 2H], [2.05 (s), 2.04 (m), 3H], [2.39 (m), 1.73–1.71 (m), 2H], [1.45 (s), 1.44 (s), 9H]; MS (ES) m/z: 367.19 [M + 1]+.
    Step b
    tert-Butyl (3-(([1,1′-biphenyl]-4-ylmethyl) (methyl)amino)cyclobutyl)carbamate was converted to 57 according to method A: 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.6–7.58 (m, 2H), 7.56 (d, J = 8.0, 2H), 7.45 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.36–7.32 (m, 3H), 4.2 (m, 1H), 3.41 (s, 2H), 3.27 (m, 1H), 2.41–2.38 (m, 4H), 2.06 (s, 3H); MS (ES) m/z: 309.1221 [M + 1]+; purity: 99%, retention time: 6.95 min.

    5-(3-Fluoro-4-methoxyphenyl)-2-((1s,3s)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutyl)isoindoline (58)

    This compound was prepared from 5-bromoisoindoline according to methods A and C. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.38 (m, 2H), 7.32–7.24 (m, 3H), 7.04 (t, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 3.85 (s, 3H), 3.77 (m, 1H), 3.3–3.2 (m, 1H), 2.9–2.8 (m, 2H), 2.6–2.5 (m, 1H), 2.35–2.45 (m, 1H), 2.25–2.1 (m, 2H); MS (ES) m/z: 354.1183 [M + 1]+; purity: 98%, retention time: 6.05 min.

    6-(3-Fluoro-4-methoxyphenyl)-2-((1s,3s)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-isoquinoline (59)

    This compound was prepared from 6-bromo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline according to methods A and C (Scheme 3). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 7.31 (m, 1H), 7.27–7.26 (m, 3H), 7.09 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.02 (t, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 3.92 (s, 3H), 3.89–3.85 (m, 1H), 3.54 (m, 2H), 2.96 (t, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H), 2.74–2.7 (m, 3H), 2.65 (t, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H), 2.28–2.27 (m, 2H); MS (ES) m/z: 368.1276 [M + 1]+; purity: 97%, retention time: 6.15 min.

    Method D (Scheme 4)

    5-(3-Fluoro-4-methoxyphenyl)-N-((1s,3s)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutyl)picolinamide (61)

    Step a
    To a suspension of 5-bromopicolinic acid (404 mg, 2.0 mmol), tert-butyl (cis-3-aminocyclobutyl) carbamate (372 mg, 2.0 mmol) and N-ethyl-N-diisopropyl amine (750 mg, 6.0 mmol) in anhydrous dichloromethane (20 mL) at room temperature were added dimethylformamide (DMF) (0.5 mL), EDC (480 mg, 2.5 mmol), and HOBt (338 mg, 2.5 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, diluted with methylene chloride (20 mL), and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 (10 mL). The aqueous layer was further extracted twice with methylene chloride (10 mL). The combined organics were dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvents were removed under vacuum, and the residue was purified on silica gel (Biotage; eluting solvents: hexanes/EtOAc in a 1/1 ratio) to afford tert-butyl ((1s,3s)-3-(5-bromopicolinamido) cyclobutyl)carbamate (562 mg, 76% yield); 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.58 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H); 8.05 (dd, J = 8.0 Hz J = 2.0 Hz, 1H); 7.96 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H); 7.95 (br s, 1H); 4.71 (br s, 1H), 4.27–4.17 (m, 1H); 3.89–3.80 (m, 1H); 2.88–2.84 (m, 2H); 1.87–1.80 (m, 2H); 1.43 (s, 9H); MS (ES) m/z: 370.12 [M + 1]+.
    Step b
    tert-Butyl ((1s,3s)-3-(5-bromopicolinamido) cyclobutyl)carbamate was converted to 61 and 57 according to method A: 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.72 (d, J = 2 Hz, 1H), 8.21 (t, J = 8, 10 Hz, 2H), 7.98 (dd, J = 2.5, 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.38 (m, 2H), 7.11 (t, J = 8, 9.5 Hz, 1H), 4.42–4.36 (m, 1H), 3.96 (s, 3H), 3.94–3.91 (m, 2H), 2.39–2.33 (m, 2H); MS (ESI) m/z: 358.4412 [M + 1]+.

    5-(3-Fluoro-4-methoxyphenyl)-N-((1s,3s)-3-isothiocyanatocyclobutyl)pyridine-2-sulfonamide (66)

    Step a
    To a stirring solution of 4-bromobenzene-sulfonyl chloride (172 mg, 0.67 mmol) in dichloromethane (5 mL) at room temperature were added tert-butyl (cis-3-aminocyclobutyl) carbamate (150 mg, 0.81 mmol) and diisopropylethylamine (0.23 mL, 1.34 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 18 h, then diluted with EtOAc, and washed with water and saturated solution of ammonium chloride. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvents were removed under vacuum to afford tert-butyl((1s,3s)-3-((4-bromophenyl) sulfonamide) cyclobutyl)carbamate (233 mg, 86% yield) as a white solid; 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 8.02–8.05 (m, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 9 Hz, 2H), 7.71 (d, J = 9 Hz, 2H), 7.08–7.06 (m, 1H), 3.49–3.44 (m, 1H), 3.28–3.21 (m, 1H), 2.25–2.18 (m, 2H), 1.68–1.61 (m, 2H), 1.33 (s, 9H); MS (ESI) m/z: 405.14 [M + 1]+.
    Step b
    tert-Butyl((1s,3s)-3-((4-bromophenyl) sulfonamide) cyclobutyl)carbamate was converted to 66 according to Method A: 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 8.10 (d, J = 10 Hz, 1H), 7.86 (dd, J = 25, 9 Hz, 4H), 7.72 (d, J = 9.5 Hz, 2H), 7.08 (d, J = 9 Hz, 2H), 3.94–3.86 (m, 1H), 3.82 (s, 3H), 3.51–3.42 (m, 1H), 2.56–2.49 (m, 2H), 2.04–1.97 (m, 2H); MS (ESI) m/z: 375.4911 [M + 1]+.

    Biochemical Pharmacology

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    NAAA Inhibitor Fluorescence Assay

    Compounds were assessed in a fluorescence-based assay for NAAA inhibition with PAMCA as the substrate.(57) For three-point concentration inhibition assays with hNAAA, the following procedure was used. Purified activated hNAAA(57,74) (final concentration of 0.25 μg/mL) was incubated in assay buffer (100 mM citrate-phosphate buffer, pH 4.5, 3 mM DTT, 0.1% Triton X-100, 0.05% bovine serum albumin (BSA), and 150 mM NaCl) made up to a total volume of 180 μL, followed by the addition of the compound dissolved in 10 μL of DMSO (along with DMSO neat for the control sample) with the final concentrations for each compound of 100, 10, and 1 μM, in triplicate on a 96 well plate. These samples were allowed to incubate for 90 min at room temperature, and then, 10 μL of a PAMCA stock solution in DMSO (final PAMCA concentration [5 μM]) was added. After 5 min of agitation on a shaking plate, the reaction was allowed to proceed at 37 °C for 90 min, with fluorescence readings taken every 10 min at a wavelength of 460 nm (using an excitation wavelength of 360 nm) on a Synergy HT Plate Reader using Gen5 software from Bio-Tek. The enzyme activity was calculated by converting the relative fluorescence units to AMC formed, using a standard curve of AMC. For compounds that inhibited hNAAA in range IC50 < 1 μM, full inhibition curves using eight different concentrations of inhibitor (8-point assay) were generated. The assay procedure used was the same as the three-point assay. Inhibition constants were calculated using pro Fit software (Quantum Soft, Switzerland) and a Levenberg–Marquardt.

    Determination of NAAA Potencies (kinact/Ki Values)

    The potency of NAAA inhibitors was determined by the second-order rate constants kinact/Ki values using an enzyme-coupled NAAA assay in 96-well microplates as described previously.(75) The overall potency, kinact/Ki values, was calculated from the slope, kinact/[Ki(1 + [S]/Km)], which was obtained from the kobs equation as described.(76) NAAA inactivation rates in the absence of inhibitors were subtracted from all kobs values obtained in the presence of inhibitors.

    MGL and FAAH Inhibitor Fluorescence Assay

    Human-recombinant FAAH (hFAAH) and MGL (hMGL) were expressed in Escherichia coli and purified as described.(61) A high-throughput fluorometric screening assay for FAAH inhibition using a fluorescent substrate, AAMCA, was performed as reported.(59) MGL assays used the fluorescent substrate arachidonoyl, 7-hydroxy-6-methoxy-4-methylcoumarin ester (AHMMCE).(61) IC50 values were calculated using Prism software (GraphPad).

    ABHD6 Inhibitor Fluorescence Assay

    Compounds were assessed in a high throughput fluorescence-based assay for their ability to inhibit the full-length hABHD6 enzyme. We used the fluorogenic substrate arachidonoyl, 7-hydroxy-6-methoxy-4-methylcoumarin ester (AHMMCE)(61) that is hydrolyzed to the fluorescent product HMMCE in the presence of active ABHD6 enzyme.

    Cathepsin K Assay

    Compounds were pre-incubated for 120 min at 37 °C recombinant human Cathepsin K enzyme (Enzo; BML-SE553-0010). We used the fluorogenic substrate Z-Phe-Arg-AMC (Enzo; BML-P139) for the reaction, and the enzyme activity was measured from the increase of OD at 405 nm.(77)

    rCB1, hCB2, and mCB2 Binding Assay

    The selected compounds were tested for their ability to bind to CB1 and CB2 receptors using the rat brain(63) or HEK293 cell membranes expressing mouse CB2 (mCB2) or human CB2 (hCB2),(64−66) respectively, via competition-equilibrium binding using [3H]CP-55,940.(65−67,78)

    Stability in Plasma and Buffer

    Compound solutions (200 μM) were made in mouse, rat, or human plasma, buffer containing 0.1% BSA, or artificial gastric juice. After quenching with acetonitrile, the samples were analyzed by HPLC to predict plasma half-lives.(79,80)

    Stability toward Rat Liver Microsomal Preparations

    Compound solutions (1 μM) were pre-incubated with the rat liver microsomal protein (Celsis) at 37 °C before the reaction was initiated with NADPH or buffer (control).(81,82) Following protein precipitation, the samples were analyzed using a LC–MS/MS system in the SRM mode.

    Pharmacokinetic Study of Compound 36

    Male CD-1 mice (25–30 g) from Charles River were used to determine the oral bioavailability and brain exposure of 36 after intravenous (iv) and oral (po) administration. Animals were fasted overnight prior to dosing and until 4-h post-dose. Mice were given 2 mg/kg of compound 36 intravenously and 8 mg/kg orally in 3% DMSO, 1:1:18 Emulphor/ethanol/saline vehicle.

    Blood Sampling Time Points

    After iv injection, plasma samples were taken at the following time points: pre-dose 0 min, at 2, 5, 15, and 30 min and 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 h. After po administration, plasma samples were taken at pre-dose 0 min, then at 15 and 30 min and 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 h.

    Brain Sampling Time Points

    After iv injection, blood sampling was done at time points 0, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, and 6 h. The plasma samples were flash-frozen with liquid nitrogen to prevent the post-mortem degradation of the compounds. We homogenized the brain in 10 mL of water and freezed it as soon as possible. We have used three animals per time point. The animals were sacrificed by decapitation followed by blood collection (500 μL) and tissue dissection; samples are flash-frozen with liquid nitrogen to prevent the post-mortem degradation of the compounds. The animals were sacrificed by cervical dislocation followed by decapitation, at which point, the trunk blood will be collected and tissues harvested; this method is consistent with the June 2007 AVMA Guidelines on Euthanasia and our IACUC-approved animal protocol (#16-0402R). Northeastern University’s animal assurance number is #A-3155.

    Computational Studies

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Modeling Methods

    The computational studies were conducted in Schrodinger Suite (version 2018-3). The ligands were prepared in the OPLSe3 force field using the Ligprep module.(83) Induced-fit docking(84) and covalent docking(55) used Glide and was conducted in the XP (extra precision) mode in the OPLS3e force field.(85,86) MM-GBSA rescoring was conducted using the Prime module.

    Computational (In Silico) Analysis of Physicochemical Properties of Ligands

    In silico ligand screening with commercial computational software (Schrodinger Suite 2018-3) was used to assess early ADME/pharmacokinetic properties of the proposed compounds in areas of Lipinski rules, ligand efficiency, topological polar surface area (tPSA), and lipophilicity (Clog P).
